bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to A.V. McClain, February 12, 1941

div1.p: Hench thanks McClain for the additional brochures. He is curious to see the film made during the dedication ceremony of the Lazear Building.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to A.V. McClain, February 12, 1941
div1.opener:
Y. F.
February 12, 1941
Mr. A. V. McClain
Washington and Jefferson College
Washington, Pennsylvania
My dear Mr. McClain:
div1.p:
You were kind indeed to send
me the extra package of “Mile Posts” and I will certainly
make use of them.

I will be very glad indeed to see
your film. There might be some scenes that I should like
to have.

I have written Mr. Andrus, one of
the other survivors of the yellow fever experiments. As a
matter of fact, there are three or four others somewhere
around the country. Andrus himself has been bedridden for
years. The reason that Kissinger and Moran were considered
to be the more suitable representatives was that they vol-
unteered for the experiments freely, whereas all the other
men, including Andrus, took the matter on for the money in-
volved, which was $200.00. Nevertheless, I am glad you
sent Andrus a booklet, and I intend to correspond with him
further.
div1.closer: Very truly yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
